messages: edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:25): "<s> does not mean that content is subject for removing. The content was
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:25): marked up with <s> at the same exact moment it was created; it was
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:25): purposedly marked up like that. It's like when you say "A, err... I mean
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:25): B", and you said A not because you have mistaken, but because you were
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:25): really wanting to say it like that - a, err..., i mean b."
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:26): I think it's sort of a valid use case
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:26): It would also apply to the earlier given example
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:26): i think del should be defined to be appropriate for such cases... :)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:27): That would work too
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (15:29): bugzilla uses <s> for marking up links to bugs that are resolved (at least it did last time I checked)
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:29): yeah, there <del> would not appropriate I think
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:30): title="Resolved"
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:30): [title=Resolved] { text-decoration:strike-through }
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:30): no backpat?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:30): what's the compat problem?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:30): legacy UAs
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:30): that don't support attribute selectors?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:31): for instance
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:31): the information is still there, if you hover the link you will get a tooltip
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (15:32): looks like bugzilla has since been updated to use <span class="bz_closed"> and other similar classes
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:32): using a class could solve the attribute selectors limitation
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:33): using <s> could solve all problems simpler
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:34): perhaps, but it doesn't really mean "resolved", does it?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:34): it means "less relevant"
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:34): a reader could figure it out though
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:35): or something in that direction
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (15:35): if we add <s>, then who wants to volunteer to handle the huge backlash from those same people that object to <b>, <i>, etc?

cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:37): btw, i discussed with cerbera the other day about html5's suggested markup for different kinds if user input is very verbose and seems to be semantics for semantics' sake
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:37): nested kbd/samp doesn't help the reader understand the text better
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:37): and UAs probably can't do anything useful with the information
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:38): i've tried to style the proposed markup with css but even that doesn't really help. for styling it is better to have a class on the outermost element
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (15:39): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0, yeah, that sections really just more like suggested conventions for authors, rather than something useful for consumers
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (15:39): that's why we need parent selectors! ;-)
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:40): in the wild, <kbd> is already used for at least keys that the user is to press
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:40): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: why are the conventions useful for authors except for self-congratulation about semantics?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (15:40): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, I never said they were useful
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:41): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: ah. just conventions :-)

cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:42): perhaps kbd can be defined to mean any kind of user input, e.g. text that the user is to type, or keys the user is to press, or menu items the user is to follow
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:42): checks out molly.com and is surprised

f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (15:43): in general, coding conventions are useful, particularly in collaborative environments, but when it comes to purely semantic conventions with little practical purpose, doesn't seem useful at all
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:43): <kbd><kbd><samp> is just extremely verbose
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (15:44): <kbd><kbd>Alt</kbd>+<kbd>F4</kbd></kbd> is a useful convention since it allows for easy styling of individual keys
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:44): <kbd>Alt</kbd>+<kbd>F4</kbd>
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:44): seems enough to me
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:44): hmm
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:45): you might want to style them as block...
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (15:45): it depends if you want your stylesheet to distinguish between text to enter and sequences of keys to press
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:45): follows the spec already
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:45): so I'm prolly biased
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (15:46): f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220: perhaps. though classes can be used
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (15:46): e.g. giving instructions like this to users: "Enter "<kbd>format C:</kbd>" and then press <kbd><kbd>Enter</kbd></kbd>.

b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (15:46): here's something for a potentially rathole sematic debate: If you have a file system path or a URI on a Web page, should it have specific markup and if yes, which?
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (15:47): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9, I use <code> for both
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:47): uses <code> for URIs
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:48): isn't sure why
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (15:48): ... just to get a monospace font
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (15:49): one could possibily argue that <a>http://...</a> is the right markup
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:49): without href?
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:49): hmm
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:50): that'd be wrong actually
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (15:50): either with or without.  It depends i
f139aba52f9fa1394b4034a7954b2220 (15:50): yeah, it'd be wrong with the current HTML5 definition

425fb52813381a0bc3fce51541c8ca72 (15:57): hmm, why should an HTML5 parser close the first a element right after the closing tag of the first table element with test #30 on http://jero.net/lab/ph5p/tests.html ???
425fb52813381a0bc3fce51541c8ca72 (15:57): that's what html5lib does anyway

425fb52813381a0bc3fce51541c8ca72 (15:58): http://hasather.net/html5/parsetree/parsetree?source=%3Ca%3E%3Ctable%3E%3Ctd%3E%3Ca%3E%3Ctable%3E%3C%2Ftable%3E%3Ca%3E%3C%2Ftr%3E%3Ca%3E%3C%2Ftable%3E%3Cb%3EX%3C%2Fb%3EC%3Ca%3EY
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (15:59): it needs to reopen because it hits some other <a> element
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (16:00): you mean why does it result in "...</table></a><a><b>..." as opposed to just "...</table><b>..."?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (16:01): perhaps it's a bug in html5lib -- what does the spec say? :)
425fb52813381a0bc3fce51541c8ca72 (16:03): can't find anything in the spec, but doesn't seem very logical to close an a element after a table element or before a b element
7bdef05e587492e995e6a0ae56335270 (16:14): (Opera's IRC is much prettier than mIRC)
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (16:16): 7bdef05e587492e995e6a0ae56335270: see logs from 14:37 for the kbd discussion
7bdef05e587492e995e6a0ae56335270 (16:17): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: I read from <http://krijnhoetmer.nl/irc-logs/whatwg/20070615#l-294>
7bdef05e587492e995e6a0ae56335270 (16:18): In making websites, I have yet to need more than one level of <kbd> for styling or any other purpose
7bdef05e587492e995e6a0ae56335270 (16:19): I think styling is the only purpose for that element, in practise.
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (16:20): good enough reason to keep it around :)
7bdef05e587492e995e6a0ae56335270 (16:21): yes, me too. but it doesn't need to be nested in practise
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:21): gaah. I chose a JSON impl that can take a byte stream so that it could handle encodings per spec. Does it? Nooo.
7bdef05e587492e995e6a0ae56335270 (16:24): so if <kbd>foo</kbd> is adequate for styling purposes, why make its semantics more specific so they require extra levels?

7bdef05e587492e995e6a0ae56335270 (16:24): as I said to cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 yesterday: "it's not like double-clicking styled text is going to start up an external application and perform that action"
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:25): jgraham: what's the logic in tokenizer test character coalescing?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (16:26): 7bdef05e587492e995e6a0ae56335270: you wanna summarize the information here and send to the list? :)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:26): Why are there two tokens here:
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:26): Expected tokens:
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (16:26): ["ParseError",["Character","&"],["Character","f"]]
7bdef05e587492e995e6a0ae56335270 (16:27): cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0: although I'm supposed to be doing work :P
7bdef05e587492e995e6a0ae56335270 (16:32): so then: 1) UAs can't do anything with the information. For starters, the application it's for isn't declared.
7bdef05e587492e995e6a0ae56335270 (16:33): 2) a single level of either <kbd> or <samp> is enough for common styling needs
7bdef05e587492e995e6a0ae56335270 (16:35): 3) it's much more convenient to write '<kbd>File</kbd> > <kbd>Exit</kbd>' than '<kbd><kbd><samp>File</samp></kbd> > <kbd><samp>Exit</samp</kbd></kbd>'
7bdef05e587492e995e6a0ae56335270 (16:36): 4) fiddly markup inevitably causes confusion and is written wrongly (is that a legitimate comment?)
7bdef05e587492e995e6a0ae56335270 (16:37): (case in point: my example was wrong! missing > at the end of a </samp>)
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (16:42): that about sums it up, although it's good to put forward the counter arguments too (allows for different styling)
7bdef05e587492e995e6a0ae56335270 (16:43): 5) people can nest the elements if they like (e.g. for more complex styling) without this being required
7bdef05e587492e995e6a0ae56335270 (16:48): are there any there any other arguments for keeping it?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (16:50): not afaict
7bdef05e587492e995e6a0ae56335270 (16:51): perhaps some feel it adds clarity to the intention markup by being more specific?
cc097e0d7183ae8436e7df709553c8c0 (16:54): only for people who have read the spec and is peeking at the source code when reading a web page
7bdef05e587492e995e6a0ae56335270 (16:55): yeah, like content authors. I'm havn't seen it suggested, though.
7bdef05e587492e995e6a0ae56335270 (16:56): the context of the sentence would make clear what type if input is being talked about, I suppose
7bdef05e587492e995e6a0ae56335270 (16:56): ok, looks like 1-5 sums it up (perhaps better written)
